title: Paradox Mobile Game
long_description: Paradox is a 2D temporal puzzle game I developed, inspired by the time-inversion mechanics from the film Tenet.

The core gameplay loop allows the player to invert their personal flow of time. This causes them to move backward through the world, observing their own past actions in reverse. By re-verting to forward time, the player creates a new "self" on the timeline, allowing them to cooperate with their own past selves to solve complex puzzles.

The game also features inverted physics objects. For example, an "inverted bomb" doesn't explode; it implodes, sucking in energy and freezing its surroundings, as its entropy is reversed relative to the world.

• Core Mechanic: The entire Tenet-style time system is powered by a complex, custom data structure I designed from scratch. This structure manages multiple, simultaneous timelines for each "self" (past, inverted, and present) and allows for the data to be read both forwards and backwards seamlessly.

• Monetization: I integrated an ad mediation platform to manage and optimize ad revenue by having multiple providers bid for ad spots. I also implemented an In-App Purchase (IAP) system for an "Ad-Free" option.
• Platform: Published and available on both the iOS App Store and Google Play Store.

gallery.caption: Recording Your Time 'Footprint'
gallery.description: To allow inversion, the game constantly records 'Moments' of Position, Direction, and IsMoving status (15 times a second). This data acts like a 'footprint' in time. I smooth this data so when you watch your past selves, their movement is fluid, not jerky.

gallery.caption: Visualizing Your Path Through Time
gallery.description:
This diagram visualizes how you exist on the timeline:

  • Top Row (Green): This is your original path, moving forward in time.
  • Middle Row (Red): You've 'inverted,' moving backward from Moment 4 to Moment 2 and watching your original self's actions in reverse.
  • Bottom Row (Green): You 're-vert' at Moment 2, moving forward again and co-existing with your other selves.

gallery.caption: How All Your 'Selves' Appear at Once
gallery.description:
This shows the magic that lets you see multiple 'yous' at once. I use a dictionary to group all 'selves' by the 'Moment' they are in.

For example, at 'Moment 3', the game looks up that key and finds:

  • Your original 'past-past self' (top row).
  • Your 'inverted self' (middle row).
  • Your current self (bottom row).

It then displays all three on-screen, all moving in their respective directions.
